Christmas After the Hurricane: Spirit Shines in Lights, Donated Toys
Eds: Leea in 9th graf is cq
With LaserPhoto
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For thousands in the area devastated by Hurricane Hugo, the traditional Southern Christmas Day feast will come in a cardboard box donated by the Salvation Army. So much has been lost by so many, and yet the spirit of the season shines through. It's there in Christmas lights twinkling for the first time in Charleston's Historic District; it's there in acts of kindness, small and large. ``I wanted to do something to help. This seemed the best thing to do,'' Ray Cook said as he helped wire a new house in Mount Pleasant for Elizabeth Edwards, who lost her home to Hugo's 135 mph winds. Cook, who lives in Aiken, and a friend, Bruce McLauchlin of Hopewell, Va., spent a week of this month helping build the 832-square-foot house. Both the home and their labor were donated. The new house is ``the best thing that's happened in my whole life,'' said Mrs. Edwards, who hopes to move in with her niece and her niece's daughter by Christmas. Meanwhile, donated toys are pouring into the state from across the nation to provide a brighter Christmas for other families hit hard by the storm. At least 30,000 toys have been contributed and social service officials say the total should climb much higher as Christmas nears. Five days before Christmas, the Toys for Tots campaign in Charleston had received 18,000 toys _ 10,000 more than it distributed last year _ and hundreds more were expected, said Staff Sgt. Ozell Register, chairman of the Marine Reserve-sponsored effort. Another collection effort was launched by a Beaufort couple, Bud and Evelyn Culbertson, after their 6-year-old daughter, Leea, started crying when she saw pictures of Hugo's devastation. ``She was concerned about the kids. She wanted to give away all of her toys,'' Culbertson said. The family has collected about 15,000 toys since late September, he said. Meanwhile, there's still a keen demand for food, furniture, blankets and kerosene heaters among storm victims three months after Hugo slammed into South Carolina at Charleston on Sept. 21, said Capt. Jim Worthy, the Salvation Army commander for Charleston. The storm left 29 dead in South Carolina and $6 billion in damage. Last Christmas, the Salvation Army donated about 1,600 Christmas baskets containing food for a family of four for a week. This year, about 4,500 will be distributed. But, Worthy said, the demand will continue long after Christmas. ``We have adequate food right now. We're getting a lot of Christmas help. Traditionally, after Christmas it will stop and that's when the real crunch will come,'' he said. In Charleston, Christmas lights have blossomed in places they were never seen before _ on the palmettos along Broad Street and lining the old Citadel building on Calhoun Square, making the structure look like a fairy tale castle. ``We decided to do everything possible to show Christmas,'' said Howard Chapman, coordinator of the city's relief effort. ``I think people appreciate that. It gives them something to look forward to and the children the hope the community is coming back.'' Part of the display is the 89-foot Norway spruce which dominates King Street. Strung with a mile of lights, the tree is believed to be among the largest Christmas trees in the nation. ``This is a very special Christmas for all of us in our community,'' Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. told thousands who turned out for the tree lighting. ``Our community has shown we have the Christmas spirit. I saw people who lost their homes who were concerned about their fellow man. This year we have so much thanks _ so much to be thankful for.'' While the displays are helping weekend shopping business, there's concern that seasonal business is lagging because of a misconception that downtown buildings were gutted by the storm. Kris Holmes of the Market Area Merchants Association said the association's 250 members are taking out ads _ in addition to regular holiday advertising _ to dispel that misconception. Meanwhile, business at suburban shopping centers is brisk. Sales are up from last year, said Shirley Webb, assistant manager of the Children's Palace store in West Ashley. ``My personal opinion is it's because of the hurricane,'' she said. Customers are ``making up for some of the inconveniences, especially for the children, and they're going to make this Christmas better than before.''
